title: TCPSocketConnection::set_blocking(bool blocking, unsigned int 	timeout) looks wrong
body:
i think `bool blocking` should true when blockingmode. 
And in [docs page](https://developer.mbed.org/users/mbed_official/code/Socket/docs/434906b5b977/classSocket.html#a43e33b8b5b27d410e6ace6c37dbaeb52), written same thing as above.
But in [example page](https://developer.mbed.org/handbook/Socket) and in code ([Socket::set_blocking](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/03fff9249b0ca5efb2e12506ce8fb3e6cc258d9d/libraries/net/lwip/Socket/Socket.cpp), [TCPSocketConnection::send](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/03fff9249b0ca5efb2e12506ce8fb3e6cc258d9d/libraries/net/lwip/Socket/TCPSocketConnection.cpp)), blocking mode is enable when `blocking == false`

which is correct?

title: Update pwmout_api.c
body:
Line 244 changed PclkFreq_2 to PcklFreq
Line 246 changed PclkFreq to PclkFreq_2

This is proposed as the current pwmout_api.c gives the wrong period/frequency when using e.g."mypwm.period_ms(1);"
For PWM1 1ms gave 500Hz and PWM2,3 and 4 gave 2KHz

Applied to source as above and re-compiled this gave 1KHz outputs for all PWM's selected
Tried on NUCLEO STM32F401RE will effect other NUCLEO-STM32F4 as above

HAL Clocks are as follows for the F401RE Board:  PCLK1=42000000 PCLK2=84000000 HCLK=84000000

Kind Regards

Martin

title: [Exporter] Derive codered/lpcxpresso exporter templates from a common template
body:
Since all .project files are the same, all templates derive from one common template. The .cproject file differ across the cores and use other MCU configurations (memory maps etc). 

Note1:
For the Cortex M4 exporter, only the .project template was adapted. The cproject exporter is unchanged for now, since the given core (cm3 instead of cm4, see codered_lpc4330_m4_cproject.tmpl) and the floating point definitions differ. This should be fixed before using a common template for the CM4 cores.

Note2:
The exported projects from workspace_tools/export_test.py do not build for the Cortex M0 MCUs due to a compilation issue in RTX.

title: EFM32 initial stackpointer for (u)ARM is wrong
body:
@stevew817 (At least I assume I should bother you with it)

If you look at random other target, the initial stack pointer is set to top of the RAM: https://developer.mbed.org/users/mbed_official/code/mbed-src/file/53297373a894/targets/cmsis/TARGET_Freescale/TARGET_KLXX/TARGET_KL25Z/TOOLCHAIN_ARM_MICRO/startup_MKL25Z4.S

For all EFM32 targets I checked it is not explicitly set, and I have no idea how the compiler handles it exactly: https://developer.mbed.org/users/mbed_official/code/mbed-src/file/53297373a894/targets/cmsis/TARGET_Silicon_Labs/TARGET_EFM32/TARGET_EFM32WG_STK3800/TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD/startup_efm32wg.S

What is the result? The zero gecko has, as long as it fits within compile time, ALWAYS 300-400B of memory to use at runtime. If you have an empty program, it has 300-400B available. If you define a global array of 1kB, it still has 300-400B available. This means you can allocate only an extremly limited amount of data at runtime. 

For the wonder gecko a quick test showed me about 4kB of data, which is still way short of the amount of RAM it has. 

A simple program which iterates until it crashes because it filled its own stack could do 21 runs on a zero gecko, while on an LPC812 it did 222 runs. Also the first 4 bytes of the flash are always the initial stackpointer, and that shows that that is indeed the problem.

And in addition to that there is the much higher memory usage at compile time than for other similar targets, any idea what causes that?

title: [USBDevice] PC's wont boot with device plugged in using large descriptor (>1500b)
body:
Using the standard Force Feedback Joystick descriptor with this USBDevice library many of our systems refuse to boot while device is connected.

The descriptor I am using is here: http://www.microchip.com/forums/FindPost/378772

If device is connected after system has booted everything is working normally.

Turning off Legacy USB 2.0 support in BIOS options seems to help in some cases, but this is not ideal because then the keyboard will not work in BIOS after.

This happens with many newer model motherboards from ASRock, MSI and only with a large descriptor (~1500 bytes).

Core of the issue seems to be the handling of BIOS descriptor requests and it is difficult to debug, but easily reproducible. (Lockup occurs after descriptor is read into CONTROL_TRANSFER packet)

Any idea what I could change to resolve this or debug this further?

I have created a latch system that sends a small descriptor then resets the mbed some seconds later then sends the larger descriptor.. but this is a bit too hacky (sometimes causes windows to reboot the system if i do not reset device at the right moment) and I'm considering switching to a different board, because I have had success using the same descriptor on other platforms (other usb stacks).

title: [mbed] Modified MBED_ASSERT to use error()

title: add IBDAP-LPC11U35 platform
body:
This pull request is for adding Armstart IBDAP-LPC11U35 board to the mbed supported platforms.

---
# IBDAP

IBDAP is a fully CMSIS-DAP compatible debug adapter. It provides vendor independent debug interface between your PC over USB and target ARM device over JTAG/SWD pins. You can do debugging functions like stepping, breakpoints, watch points and firmware download etc. It's fully supported by Keil, OpenOCD, GNU GDB, IAR and other commonly used debugging tools.
# Why IBDAP?

Debug adapters are expensive, some could cost thousands of dollars, some may not be compatible among different vendors. Luckily, ARM standardized the debugging interface which is called CMSIS-DAP and released the firmware implementation on some processors, however, you still need a Keil MDK Professional edition software in order to build the firmware, even the open source one provided by mbed and the price for Keil Professional is intimidating. All these barriers has become the first issue that every inventor is facing, and we need a solution!

IBDAP's objective is to become an affordable open source & open hardware CMSIS-DAP JTAG/SWD debug probe implementation using gcc & makefile. Anyone can modify and embed a debug probe on its own device easily with everything under its control.
# mbed enabled

Besides being functioning as a JTAG/SWD debug probe, IBDAP could also be used as a general mbed development board. It has an ARM Cortex M0 processor  running at 48Mhz and has peripherals like UART, I2C, SPI, USB. It can be used in many applications like USB audio devices, USB mouse/keyboards, USB mass storage devices, USB-TTL adapter device and many many more. Moreover, the 10-bit high precision ADC peripheral also makes IBDAP an ideal device for any sensor projects. 

![IBDAP pinout](https://s3.amazonaws.com/armstart/Debug+Tools/IBDAP-LPC11U35/7.jpg)
# Schematic and Source Codes

Schematic: [https://s3.amazonaws.com/armstart/Debug+Tools/IBDAP-LPC11U35/IBDAP-LPC11U35_SCH.pdf](https://s3.amazonaws.com/armstart/Debug+Tools/IBDAP-LPC11U35/IBDAP-LPC11U35_SCH.pdf)

Source code: [https://github.com/Armstart-com/IBDAP-CMSIS-DAP](https://github.com/Armstart-com/IBDAP-CMSIS-DAP)
# How to use IBDAP to debug target board

Connect IBDAP's TGT_DBG 10-pin header to the target board (note, VTREF pin at TGT_DBG provides 3.3V for the target board, but you can switch off by removing the corresponding jumper), connect IBDAP and PC via USB cable.

If your system is Windows, you should be able to see a USB HID device called "IBDAP-LPC11U35 CMSIS-DAP" in your control panel.
## If you are using Keil

From your Keil project, click on "Options for Target" button just besides the target, choose "Debug" tab, select use: "CMSIS-DAP Debugger", then click "settings", you should be able to see the "IBDAP-LPC11U35 CMSIS-DAP" device with any error, if yes, then we are all set.

![Keil options](https://s3.amazonaws.com/armstart/Debug+Tools/IBDAP-LPC11U35/howtos/keil-cmsis-dap-setting-1.JPG)

title: WIZwiki-W7500 SystemCoreClock at 20MHz instead of 48MHz
body:
A quick first test with the new WIZwiki-W7500 platform shows that the clockfrequency is 20MHz, which is less than half the advertised value of 48MHz. Turns out that this is due to the fact that the PLL freq calculation register is not initialised and uses its reset value of 0x050200 instead. That means the PLL config values are: M=5, N=2, OD=1. So the SystemCoreClock = 8MHz \* M / N \* 1 / OD = 20 MHz

This bug should be fixed in the W7500 mbed source code, probably in system_W7500x.c, for example by adding:
CRG->PLL_FCR = 0x060100;      

I also noted that the internal Xtal (8MHz) is used instead of the (mounted) external Xtal (8 MHz). Any reason for that?

title: Nordic: add const qualifier to acceptedSpeeds in serial API
body:
This is a small optimisation for ARM compiler toolchains: constant
arrays should be declared const explicitly, to let the compiler put them
into .rodata instead of .data. GCC automatically detects that the array
is read-only, and already puts it into flash.

This way, we free 136 bytes of RAM, which is nothing to sneeze at, given
that applications only get about 2048 bytes by default, on 16k targets.

Please note that you will need to disable data compression in armlink to
see the actual difference, using the "--datacompressor off" switch, for
example.

title: Change from hard to softfp for FRDM-K64F (Cortex-M4F)
body:
Hi,

I have a posted a question in mbed forum about the change of fpu flag for FRDM-K64F from hard to softfp. This processor is having FPU by default, so It would be good to provide the mbed library with the hard enabled instead of soft.

https://developer.mbed.org/questions/54230/Mbed-library-for-K64F-is-built-with-soft/#answer7952

I have been redirected to raise an issue in this forum.

It seems, the flag is changed from hard to soft based on the following request.
 https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/pull/224/files 

My request is to change this flag to hard for the better performance. If there is a reason or requirement to build the library with softfp, then it would be good to provide both versions of libraries in the mbed library zip.

title: Nucleo STM32F401 and 411RE uart driver with 8 bits and even parity does not work
body:
On NucleoF401 and 411RE, UART driver with 8 bits and  even parity does not work.
The MSB and Parity bits interfere and hence communication does not work for UART1.

UART baud 115200 bps actually becomes 116800 bps. This also needs a correction so that it works at exact baud of 115200 bps.

title: Tools to automatically retrieve data from the mbed source files
body:
@sg-  told me to commit this :).

This is a combined effort of mainly me (@Sissors) (Idea + initial versions) and @sarahmarshy (actually knowing python is an advantage apparantly :P, so improving the code and also working further with it) . This is really work in progress, but committed for better cooperation options. 

supported.py generates an HTML table with all (official) targets and
data from device.h. This is currently searchable and filterable (click
on column headers). Supported_html.py contains the html code used.

supported_beta.py is the next step, which does not create html (yet),
but outputs in console. It searches the ARM/uARM scatter file and from
this retrieves RAM and ROM sizes.

title: feature: allow users to build static libraries (.ar) using online compiler
body: Some users, myself included, would find it incredibly useful if we could build static libraries using the online compiler.  There is at least one end-certified, production grade device supported on MBED now and it isn't always feasible to release source code to users for security or compliance reasons.  Allowing users to build a static library using the online compiler would quickly and easily solve some of those problems.

title: GCC asm updates
body:
This fixes a few things regarding asm, GCC and Eclipse.
1. Eclipse CDT needs assembly files names with .asm or .S (not lowercase) http://gnuarmeclipse.livius.net/blog/faq/#The_plug-in_seems_to_ignore_assembly_s_files_How_can_I_add_them_to_the_project
2. RTOS for Cortex-M4 with floating point uses a __FPU_PRESENT macro. Makefiles not using the c preprocessor and this CPU type would fail. Makefiles now use the assembler after the preprocessor

Tested with a CM4 MCU, RTOS, no RTOS on windows with MSYS, GNU MAKE and Ubuntu 14.04. All combinations build successfully and run without modifications.

```
import os
import sys

if __name__ == '__main__':

    if len(sys.argv) < 2:
        print 'usage: <path> <old ext> <new ext>'
        sys.exit()

    change_count = 0
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk(sys.argv[1]):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith(sys.argv[2]):
                print file
                (name, ext) = os.path.splitext(file)
                name += sys.argv[3]
                os.rename(os.path.join(root, file), os.path.join(root, name))
                print name
                change_count += 1


    print 'files changed: ', change_count
```

title: Update .hgignore
body: Ignore build directory when exporting for KDS and also eclipse .settings

title: Changing return status of singletest.py if a build failure occurs
body: Before if a build error occurred when running singletest.py, the return code would still be `0`, indicating no error. It now sets an error code of -1. Not sure if that's the right number, but at least it's nonzero :)

title: Update kds_k22f_cproject.tmpl
body: Update for KDS 3.0 using unmodified arm-gcc-eabi- tools

title: Update kds_k64f_cproject.tmpl
body: Update for KDS 3.0 using unmodified arm-gcc-eabi- tools

title: [NUCLEO_XXXX] RTOS test enhancement
body:
RTOS test main files: statck size modification for little product
F030: us_ticker modif, add hal_tick.h and hal_tick.c to add ticker and reserve systick for RTOS
F030+GCC modif startup file for RTOS

title: Added support for new RPC objects with multiple pins. Added baud func…
body: …tion for serial RPC.

title: FRDM K64F PwmOut
body: Seems like there is an issue on this board with PwmOut. No valid output on logic analyzer. Checked that PwmOut IS working for LPC1768. I am investigating it but haven't seen any obvious issues. Could use some help.

title: [MAXWSNENV,MAX32600MBED] Added ring oscillator trimming procedure.
body: Added ring oscillator trimming procedure for Maxim Integrated targets.

title: Added support for dynamic creation of RPC objects
[DISCO_F746NG] Add new target
body:
Status:
- uARM and ARM compilation with build.py is OK
- Basic tests with uVision: System init with HSE and HSI OK, tick timer OK, DigitalOut OK
- singletest.py failed (build error)

title: [RZ_A1H]Add CAN driver.
body:
Hi,

We added CAN driver.

Regards,
Yamanaka

title: Fix FPU checks
body:
Compiling produces the following results:
http://pastebin.com/3R8KJG72
It appears it's related to the latest commit to this file, which adds a few preprocessor directives checking for an FPU. Oddly enough those directives used different syntax (they were prefixed with '#' instead of '.'), and I was suggested on IRC to change it so it complies with the rest.
This is the fix.

title: NUCLEO STM32F401 UART 1200 baudrate not works
body: When any uart baudrate set to 1200 nucleo can not receive any characters/data from sensors etc by any Rx pin. When both baudrate of nucleo and other device set to 9600 everything is ok.  1200 baudrate is critical for SDI-12 based communications.

title: Update and bug fix.
body:
Update I2C driver and hal api.
Bug fix about PinMap.
Change wait function.
Uncomment gpio_set function.

title: Fix GCC compilation warnings.
body:
These trivial changes silence annoying GCC warnings that are enabled under `-Wall`.

I've annotated each one individually.

I have accepted the mbed contributor agrreement - I have the same username on mbed.org.

title: Update targets.py
body: Use ARM by default for mdot, not uARM

title: HAL_CM4.s compilation issues on Freescale FRDM-K22F (M4 with FPU)
body:
Compiling produces the following results:
http://pastebin.com/3R8KJG72
It appears it's related to the latest commit to this file, which adds a few preprocessor directives checking for an FPU. Oddly enough those directives used different syntax (they were prefixed with '#' instead of '.'), and I was suggested on IRC to change it so it complies with the rest.
It did fix the issue but it's still something that should be addressed.
Thank you.

title: Changed the way RPC commands are sent over HTTP, spaces must be URL e…
body: …ncoded.

title: Renamed the APPNEARME_MICRONFCBOARD target to MICRONFCBOARD...
body: … due to mbed website name length limitation

title: Fix KL43Z GCC_ARM build
body: sys.cpp seems to have accidentally been included in TOOLCHAIN_GCC_ARM for TARGET_KL43Z, duplicating some symbols already generated elsewhere.  This only affects KL43Z.  I don't have a proper FRDM-KL43Z, but have tested MBED_A1 and USB_4 on a variant.  Some of the other tests fail to build, but that's better than not building at all.

title: [USBDevice] LPC11UXX suspend status fix
body: The USB suspend status changed interrupt is now correctly reported on LPC11UXX platforms.

title: Update k64f_emac.c
body:
process all available packets at once. Because
the interrupt handler is triggered at an interval
and multiple packets could have been received
during that interval. Fix from private fork by Liyou Zhou

title: allow outside access to RtcHandle
body:
Since there is not yet any abstraction API for low-power wakeup timer....
The MOTE_L152RC platform needs to application access RtcHandle in order to set RTC Alarm.

RTC Alarm wakes up CPU from deep sleep, after some time delay.

title: Change target name and support InterruptIn function.
body:
I changed target name WIZwiki_W7500 to WIZWIKI_W7500.
And now WIZWIKI_W7500 support InterruptIn function.

title: uvision export doesn't include rtos & rtx source files
body:
The exporter doesn't include the rtos source files when exporting a program using rtos to uvision.  I tested this with the RTOS_1 program and NUCLEO_F411RE.  The export succeeded, but the build in uvision4 failed:

linking...
.\build\RTOS_1.axf: Error: L6218E: Undefined symbol rtos::Thread::wait(unsigned) (referred from main.o).
.\build\RTOS_1.axf: Error: L6218E: Undefined symbol rtos::Thread::Thread(void(_)(const void_), void_, osPriority, unsigned, unsigned char_) (referred from main.o).
Not enough information to list image symbols.
Finished: 1 information, 0 warning and 2 error messages.
".\build\RTOS_1.axf" - 2 Error(s), 2 Warning(s).
Target not created

The rtos and rtx source files were nowhere to be found.

title: Fix handling of Serial NC pins in K64F,K22F,KL25Z, and KL46Z
body: This pull request fixes how the Freescale boards K64F,K22F,KL25Z, and KL46Z handle having one of the serial pins set to NC.
